awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2017: Evolution of complex characters: elucidating morphological correlates to the origin of luminescent courtship behaviors of ostracods
awd_abstract_narration:
This is an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology, under the program Research Using Biological Collections. The fellow, Jessica Goodheart, is conducting research and receiving training that utilizes biological collections in innovative ways, and is being mentored by Dr. Todd Oakley at the University of California, Santa Barbara. The fellow's research focuses on the use of bioluminescence during courtship, in crustaceans called ostracods. In the animal kingdom, courtship displays using bioluminescence are relatively rare, yet occur in many types of organisms, including mollusks, arthropods, polychaetes and fish. Evidence suggests that the evolutionary origin of these displays is associated with an increase in biodiversity, within all of these different groups. This increase suggests that bioluminescent courtship behavior is an important character for speciation and evolution. The fellow seeks to determine the differences in body shape and form that may be associated with the origin of bioluminescence in ostracods and its use in this behavior. This research has the potential to provide important information regarding speciation and evolution as a general process. Finally, the fellow will be participating in multiple outreach activities, including K-12 teacher professional development and public interaction at the Marine Science Institute at the University of California, Santa Barbara.

Ostracod crustaceans of the family Cypridinidae exhibit some of the most complex courtship displays in the marine realm, which incorporate bioluminescent pulses. It is clear that there is variation in the use of luminescence during these courtship displays (e.g. peak timing of courtship and intensity of the luminescence). However, little is known about the evolution of morphological characters that may be associated with the displays. To address these gaps, this research includes two objectives: 1) generate a well-supported phylogeny of Cypridinidae, and 2) determine the differences in morphology that may be associated with the origin of bioluminescence and its use in courtship within this family. A robust phylogeny will be generated using targeted sequence capture, followed by the collection of morphological data using nano-CT technology. These data will be compared among species in the new phylogenetic framework. The fellow will be trained in targeted sequence capture and nano-CT techniques, as well as several phylogenetic comparative methods necessary for this work. In addition, the fellow will train undergraduates from groups underrepresented in the biological sciences and will lead a workshop with K-12 teachers to develop a teaching exercise on evolution based on this research.

por.por_cntn:
Under a dark, moonless sky, the warm waters of the Caribbean Sea gently lap at the reefs and shoreline along the coast. During this time begin the sexual exploits of thousands of tiny sea fireflies, called ostracods. Males attempt to court females by releasing delicate packets of glowing mucus in a pattern that evolved to attract members of their own species. Across the Caribbean, over 60 of these sea firefly species have been found, with up to 14 species in any one location. These ostracod species and others (around 100 in total, all from the family Cypridinidae) can also use their luminescence to produce large clouds of brightly glowing mucus to frighten predators, so they might swim away safely.

Most of what is known about ostracod bioluminescent courtship displays involves variation in courtship display patterns among particular species. For example, species can differ in peak timing of courtship display initiation (early evening vs. late evening for example), luminescent pulse intensity, duration of the display, interval time between pulses, and distance between pulses, among others. Chemical signature data suggests that during the display the luminescent material is released from a specific region of the male body, called the upper lip, and that this material comprises mucus mixed with various levels of the chemicals necessary for light production. This upper lip structure is also used to produce defensive bioluminescence in females and males within this group. However, little is known about the structure of the upper lip or the genes necessary for courtship display patterns to be produced, and we still do not know how the use of those genes differs between non-displaying females and the males that produce such courtship displays.  

In this NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship, I worked at the University of California, Santa Barbara. Studying under a world expert on the evolution of complex characters, Dr. Todd Oakley, I primarily used high-throughput RNA sequencing and advanced micro-computed tomography (micro-CT, a type of x-ray) approaches in multiple bioluminescent and non-bioluminescent ostracod groups. This work allows us to better understand the process of light production in this evolutionarily important group. With these approaches, I was able to generate high resolution 3D images of the upper lip structures of various ostracod species in order to compare these structures between males and females in luminous and non-luminous groups. Gene expression, or the amount of activity of a particular gene, was also collected from males and females of various species. We do see evidence of an increase in gene expression differences between males and females of the same species within species that produce bioluminescent courtship diplays. But, there is currently little evidence of different structural features in the upper lip between these same males and females.

During the award period, I presented my work at three invited seminars (two job interviews), two international meetings (Global Invertebrate Genomics Alliance and World Congress of Malacology), and two national meetings (Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology and American Malacological Society Meeting). One of my undergraduate students also presented on the life cycle and rearing of one ostracod species at the Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology meeting, and two of my undergraduates presented posters at UC Santa Barbara undergraduate research events. To date, I have one manuscript in revision from this work, and two others are in preparation (submission anticipated within 3 months). This award also allowed me to produce an additional two manuscripts submitted and four more in preparation from side projects not directly related to the project research.

This award also provided the opportunity for me to participate in a number of outreach activities during my time at UC Santa Barbara. In particular, I co-designed and co-led a workshop for female-identified middle and high school students (two times, I HEART STEM and Tech Savvy) focused on bioluminescence in animals and courtship signal diversification (materials available at: https://github.com/goodgodric28/ostracod_bioluminescence_workshop). These activities were developed, in part, around my work in the lab. I also shared my research at events such as Family Ultimate Science Exploration (FUSE), where I co-led short science experiments with local middle school students and their families (multiple events in Spring and Fall) and Nanodays, where I led short science experiments with local elementary school students and their families.
